title: cata-list
description: Useful lists of some of the best info, media, tools, and quotes for those who seek to understand and improve this world.

articles.title: Nuclear 'Power Balls' May Make Meltdowns a Thing of the Past
articles.description: Triso particles are an alien-looking fuel with built-in safety features that will power a new generation of high-temperature reactors.

articles.title: Detroit Police Chief Cops to 96-Percent Facial Recognition Error Rate
articles.description: Detroit police are under fire for a mistaken arrest using the technology.

articles.title: Scientists Say New Strain of Swine Flu Virus Is Spreading to Humans in China
articles.description: A new study warns that the strain of H1N1, common on China's pig farms since 2016, should be 'urgently' controlled to avoid another pandemic.

articles.title: US Buys Up World Stock of Key Covid-19 Drug Remdesivir
articles.description: No other country will be able to buy remdesivir, which can help recovery from Covid-19, for next three months at least

articles.title: Coronavirus Brings American Decline Out in the Open
articles.description: Without fixes for infrastructure, education, health care and government, the U.S. will resemble a developing nation in a few decades.

articles.title: Leaders Are Worse Than Average
articles.description: 'Power corrupts,' as the saying goes, and a corollary is that, other things being equal, the more power, the more corruption. That's the sort of common wisdom or deep cliché that would lead one to speculate that political leaders are likely to be morally worse on average than the populations they go…

articles.title: NATO Officials Say They Were Briefed on Russian Bounties on US Soldiers in Afghanistan — Even Though Trump Claims He Wasn't
articles.description: Three NATO officials told Insider they were briefed on the matter by US intelligence. Trump claims US intel 'did not find this info credible.'

articles.title: Radioactivity Hike Seen in Northern Europe; Source Unknown
articles.description: Nordic authorities say they detected slightly increased levels of radioactivity in northern Europe this month that Dutch officials said may be from a source in western Russia and may 'indicate damage to a fuel element in a nuclear power plant.'

articles.title: The Secretive Government Agency Planting 'Cyanide Bombs' Across the US
articles.description: Wildlife Services kills thousands of animals at ranchers and farmers' behest. But it operates with little oversight – and critics describe it as out of control

articles.title: Satellites Reveal Major New Gas Industry Methane Leaks
articles.description: Last fall, European Space Agency satellites detected huge plumes of the invisible planet-warming gas methane leaking from the Yamal pipeline that carries natural gas from Siberia to Europe.

articles.title: US Coronavirus Cases Hit New One-Day High as States Backtrack on Reopening
articles.description: Experts say there's evidence Covid-19 is making a comeback, including rising deaths and hospitalizations in parts of the US

articles.title: China's Military Provokes Its Neighbors, but the Message Is for the United States
articles.description: From the Himalayas to the South China Sea, China is pressing its territorial claims aggressively, raising the possibility of additional deadly clashes.

articles.title: Florida Governor Under Fire Over Claims State Is 'Cooking the Books' on Covid-19
articles.description: Ron DeSantis angrily dismisses allegation from fired scientist that officials are massaging figures to hide true impact of coronavirus

articles.title: A Company Run by a White House 'Volunteer' With No Experience in Medical Supplies Got $2.4 Million From the Feds for Medical Supplies
articles.description: A $2.4 million deal to supply the Bureau of Prisons with surgical gowns was the second multimillion dollar contract for coronavirus supplies that went to somebody who did work for the White House but had little relevant experience.

articles.title: DOJ's New WikiLeaks Indictment Has Significant, Convenient Plot Holes
articles.description: In its push to extradite WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange from the U.K., the U.S. Justice Department on Wednesday published a superseding indictment aimed at broadening 'the scope of the conspiracy surrounding alleged computer intrusions with which Assange was previously charged.' The names of certa…

articles.title: Why Massive Saharan Dust Plumes Are Blowing Into the US
articles.description: Every summer, an atmospheric event propels desert dust thousands of miles across the Atlantic. This year is particularly bad, and timed terribly with Covid-19.

articles.title: California Agency Blocks Release of Police Use of Force and Surveillance Training, Claiming Copyright
articles.description: Under a California law that went into effect on January 1, 2020, all law enforcement training materials must be 'conspicuously' published on the California Commission on Peace Officer Standards and Training (POST) website. However, if you visit POST's Open Data hub and try to download the officer...

articles.title: Three Cops Fired After Accidental Dashcam Activation Captures Racist Rants
articles.description: Standard, internal review of dashcam recording found 'extremely racist' footage.

articles.title: Congress Investigating How Data Broker Sells Smartphone Tracking Info to Law Enforcement
articles.description: A report last year found Homeland Security used Venntel data at the US-Mexico border.

articles.title: White House Ordered NIH to Cancel Coronavirus Research Funding, Fauci Says
articles.description: The research was the target of a conspiracy theory about the origin of the new coronavirus.

articles.title: There's Now an Even Worse Anti-Encryption Bill Than EARN IT. That Doesn't Make the EARN IT Bill OK.
articles.source: Stanford Center for Internet and Society
articles.description: The Center for Internet and Society at Stanford Law School is a leader in the study of the law and policy around the Internet and other emerging technologies.

articles.title: This Chart Shows Just How Badly the U.S. Coronavirus Response Has Damaged America's Reputation in Europe
articles.description: China's reputation has also taken a hit, according to a survey of 10,000 EU members

articles.title: FBI Expands Ability to Monitor Social Media, Location Data
articles.description: Recent contracts with Dataminr and Venntel show a growing focus on harnessing the latest private sector tools for mass surveillance.

articles.title: Roundup Maker to Pay $10 Billion to Settle Cancer Suits
articles.description: Bayer faced tens of thousands of claims linking the weedkiller to cases of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. Some of the money is set aside for future cases.

articles.title: An Algorithm That 'Predicts' Criminality Based on a Face Sparks a Furor
articles.description: Its creators said they could use facial analysis to determine if someone would become a criminal. Critics said the work recalled debunked 'race science.'

articles.title: US Moves to Exempt Companies From Reporting Harmful Chemical Releases
articles.description: The exemption allows companies to bypass an EPA law meant to address widespread contamination from perflourinated chemicals

articles.title: It's Unconstitutional for Cops to Force Phone Unlocking, Court Rules
articles.description: US courts disagree on whether suspects can be forced to unlock their phones.

articles.title: Why the Arctic Is Warming So Fast, and Why That's So Alarming
articles.description: When permafrost thaws, sea ice disappears, and wildfires rage in the north, the consequences extend to the rest of the world.

articles.title: My Family Saw a Police Car Hit a Kid on Halloween. Then I Learned How NYPD Impunity Works.
articles.description: ProPublica Deputy Managing Editor Eric Umansky's family saw an unmarked NYPD cruiser hit a Black teenager. He tried to find out how it happened, and instead found all of the ways the NYPD is shielded from accountability.

articles.title: Trump Contradicts Aides and Insists He Meant It When He Asked for Coronavirus Testing to Be Slowed Down
articles.description: Press Secretary told reporters a day earlier president was just 'joking' on Saturday night about slowing testing

articles.title: Hospitals Sued to Keep Prices Secret. They Lost.
articles.description: The decision was a victory for the Trump administration, which sees pressure from patients as a way to control health costs.

articles.title: Toxic Methanol That Causes Blindness Found in Hand Sanitizers, FDA Warns
articles.description: Methanol is toxic when ingested, inhaled, and absorbed through the skin.

articles.title: Covid-19 Has Led to a Pandemic of Plastic Pollution
articles.description: As the world produces more protective equipment—and gorges on takeaways—pity the oceans

articles.title: Climate Emission Killer: Construction Begins on World's Biggest Liquid Air Battery
articles.description: Exclusive: project will store renewable energy and reduce climate-heating emissions

articles.title: Racist Police Violence Reconsidered
articles.description: Tony Timpa was 32 years old when he died at the hands of the Dallas police in August 2016. He suffered from mental health difficulties and was unarmed. He wasn't resisting arrest. He had called the cops from a parking lot while intoxicated because he thought he might be a danger to himself. By the t…

articles.title: America's Black Communities Are Suffering. Violent Protests Will Make the Suffering Worse
articles.description: Protests sparked by the death of George Floyd at the hands of Minneapolis police officer Derek Chauvin—an act that prosecutors describe as murder—have devolved into violence. Numerous small businesses have been destroyed, and at least one elderly shopper at a Target store was assaulted. A man has be…

articles.title: Millions of Americans Can't Afford Water as Bills Rise 80% in a Decade
articles.description: Analysis of US cities shows emergency on affordability of running water amid Covid-19 pandemic

articles.title: Police Unions Spend Millions to Influence Policy in Biggest US Cities
articles.description: Analysis shows how organizations and officers in New York, Los Angeles and Chicago work against reform

articles.title: Who's to Blame for Plastic Microfiber Pollution?
articles.description: Tiny bits of plastic are corrupting every corner of the planet. The major culprits: cheap synthetic clothing and washing machines.

articles.title: Anonymous Stole and Leaked a Megatrove of Police Documents
articles.description: The so-called BlueLeaks collection includes internal memos, financial records, and more from over 200 state, local, and federal agencies.

articles.title: U.S. Watched George Floyd Protests in 15 Cities Using Aerial Surveillance
articles.description: From Minneapolis to Buffalo, Homeland Security officials dispatched drones, helicopters and airplanes to monitor Black Lives Matter protests.

articles.title: Air Force Investigates Military Planes That Monitored Protesters
articles.description: The Air Force inspector general is examining whether secretive National Guard surveillance aircraft improperly monitored demonstrators in Washington and Minneapolis.

articles.title: Arctic Records Its Hottest Temperature Ever
articles.description: Reaching 100 degrees in or near the Arctic is almost unheard of.

articles.title: 'America Is Not the Greatest Country in the World Anymore' - The Newsroom
articles.description: From the series 'the newsroom', the beginning scene. America is not the greatest country in the world anymore.

articles.title: Ten Percent of U.S. High School Students Graduating Without Basic Object Permanence Skills
articles.description: A new study finds that many American students do not realize that objects continue to exist even when they cannot be seen or heard.

articles.title: China Believed to Be Behind Major Cyber Attack on Australian Governments and Businesses
articles.description: Federal Government agencies believe China is the nation behind ongoing cyber attacks on Australian institutions, including hospitals, in recent months.

articles.title: Combining Therapy With the Psychedelic Drug Psilocybin Results in Large Reductions in Anxiety and Depression
articles.description: Psilocybin is a hallucinogenic compound found in so-called 'magic mushrooms'. A recent meta-analysis published in Psychiatry Research provides tentative ...

articles.title: U.S. Ranked Worst for Workers' Rights Among Major Economies
articles.description: The U.S. has the worst record among major developed countries when it comes to workers' rights, according to a survey of labor unions.

articles.title: Millions of Abandoned Oil Wells Are Leaking Methane, a Climate Menace
articles.description: (This June 16 story corrects comparison in paragraph eight of climate damage from methane leaks to that from U.S. oil consumption. The leaks cause climate damage roughly equivalent to typical U.S. oil consumption in one day, not two days.)

articles.title: PG&E Pleads Guilty to Manslaughter: 'Our Equipment Started the fire.'
articles.description: PG&E's 'gross negligence' led to massive 2018 Camp Fire, district attorney said.

articles.title: Massive Spying on Users of Google's Chrome Shows New Security Weakness
articles.description: A newly discovered spyware effort attacked users through 32 million downloads of extensions to Google's market-leading Chrome web browser, researchers at Awake Security told Reuters, highlighting the tech industry's failure to protect browsers as they are used more for email, payroll and other sensi…

articles.title: How to Spot Police Surveillance Tools
articles.description: Officers are likely tracking your every move at protests. But if you know what to look for, it's easy to protect yourself.

articles.title: A $1.1m Hospital Bill After Surviving the Coronavirus? That's America for You
articles.description: It shouldn't take a once-in-a-century pandemic to make policymakers understand the tragic absurdity of healthcare in the United States of America

articles.title: The Auto Industry Is Wrecked—Let's Rebuild It With Electric
articles.description: It's the perfect time for a transportation revolution: the Green-Car New Deal.

articles.title: Universities Step Up the Fight for Open-Access Research
articles.description: Today's deal between the University of California and publisher Springer Nature is a big milestone on the path to dismantling paywalls around academic journals.

articles.title: The Russian Disinfo Operation You Never Heard About
articles.description: The campaign known as Secondary Infektion appears to be a distinct effort from the meddling of the IRA and GRU—and it went undetected for years.

articles.title: You Can Now Buy Spot the Robot Dog—if You've Got $74,500
articles.description: Boston Dynamics is finally making its mechanical canine available for businesses and developers. But know that this puppy ain't for everyone.

articles.description: More than 2500 posts across 300 platforms

articles.description: Activists want demonstrators to stay active—but privacy implications abound.

articles.title: How Fighting Poverty Accidentally Stopped Deforestation
articles.description: Evidence from Indonesia shows that development goals don’t have to come at a cost to the climate.

articles.title: Zoom Shut Down US-Based Activists at China's Request
articles.description: Hackers for hire, a particularly ignominious phishing campaign, and more of the week's top security news.

articles.title: Three People With Inherited Diseases Successfully Treated With CRISPR
articles.description: Two people with beta thalassaemia and one with sickle cell disease no longer need blood transfusions after their blood stem cells were gene edited and put back in their bodies

articles.title: CEO Worked Way Up From Son of CEO
articles.description: No description provided.

articles.title: The Pandemic Is Propelling a New Wave of Automation
articles.description: Software programs adopted during the Covid-19 crisis make it easier to complete forms and track requests. It saves work, but could cost jobs.

articles.title: Powerful Petrochemical Lobbying Group Advanced Anti-Protest Legislation Amid Pandemic
articles.description: West Virginia is one of several states that have taken advantage of the pandemic to ease the construction of controversial oil and gas projects.

articles.title: Thousands of Tons of Microplastics Are Falling From the Sky
articles.description: New research helps unravel how vast amounts of plastic particles travel—both regionally and globally—on the wind

articles.description: New study begins to trace a global 'plastic cycle'

articles.title: Police Attacks on Protesters With 'Less Than Lethal' Weapons Result in Life-Threatening Injuries
articles.description: People demonstrating on the streets, or following along online, don't need studies to know that less-lethal weaponry isn't safe — particularly in crowds.

articles.title: U.S. States Accuse 26 Drugmakers of Generic Drug Price Fixing in Sweeping Lawsuit
articles.description: Twenty-six drug manufacturers were sued on Wednesday by the attorneys general of most U.S. states and several territories, which accused them of conspiring to reduce competition and drive up generic drug prices.

articles.title: 2 Million Cases and Counting: US COVID-19 Outbreak Charges on Amid Reopening
articles.description: Despite testing boosts, experts say increases are real; fear of second wave looms.

articles.title: New Facebook Tool Allows Employers to Suppress 'Unionize' in Workplace Chat
articles.description: Facebook Workplace is used by employers as large as Walmart. The new tool would allow 'content control' to prevent certain topics from trending internally.

articles.title: Siberian Officials Say Huge Diesel Spill Has Reached a Sensitive Arctic Lake
articles.description: A major diesel spill from a power plant in Siberia has reached a fragile freshwater lake that leads to the Arctic Ocean, according to regional officials. That could create an ecological catastrophe.

articles.title: MIT, Guided by Open Access Principles, Ends Elsevier Negotiations
articles.description: Institute ends negotiations for a new journals contract in the absence of a proposal aligning with the MIT Framework for Publisher Contracts.

articles.title: The Coronavirus Pandemic Isn't Ending — It's Surging
articles.description: Good news from some nations and diverted attention in others doesn't stop the fact the overall picture is very grim.

articles.title: Protesters Across US Attacked by Cars Driven Into Crowds and Men With Guns
articles.description: Protesters confronted by armed men – including members of the so-called 'boogaloo movement' – in different parts of America

articles.title: Britain Goes Coal Free as Fossil Fuels Edged Out
articles.description: On Wednesday, Britain will mark two months without burning any coal to generate power.

articles.title: Louisville Police Release the Breonna Taylor Incident Report. It's Nearly Blank
articles.description: Nearly three months after police fatally shot Breonna Taylor, the department released the incident report. It is almost entirely blank.

articles.title: Researchers Detail Huge Hack-for-Hire Campaigns Against Environmentalists
articles.description: 'The extensive targeting of American nonprofits exercising their first amendment rights is exceptionally troubling.'

articles.title: The Best Raspberry Pi Alternatives
articles.description: If you're working on a project that a Pi can't tackle, here are five single-board computers that power any DIY demand.

articles.title: Coronavirus Hospitalizations Rise Sharply in Several States Following Memorial Day
articles.description: Since Memorial Day, covid-19 hospitalizations in at least nine states have been on the rise.

articles.title: We Mapped Where Customs and Border Protection Drones Are Flying in the U.S. and Beyond
articles.description: In 2011, Rodney Brossart, a cattle rancher from Lakota, North Dakota was accused of stealing six cows. The cows, he said, simply wandered on to his 3,000-acre farm, and by his estimation, they, therefore, belonged to him. When the cops came, he and his family were prepared. Armed with high power rif…

articles.title: Police Officers Slashed Car Tires During Minneapolis Protests, Police Agencies Say
articles.description: Dozens of cars in a Kmart parking lot had all their tires slashed after public anger over George Floyd's death sparked large protests in Minneapolis.

articles.title: Hospitals Got Bailouts and Furloughed Thousands While Paying C.E.O.s Millions
articles.description: Dozens of top recipients of government aid have laid off, furloughed or cut the pay of tens of thousands of employees.

articles.title: To Save the Climate, Look to the Oceans
articles.description: They can be a source of clean, renewable energy, sustainable food, and more

articles.title: You Have a First Amendment Right to Record the Police
articles.description: Like the rest of the world, we are horrified by the videos of George Floyd's murder. Once again, police brutality was documented by brave bystanders exercising their First Amendment rights. Their videos forcefully tell a painful truth that has further fueled a movement to demand an end to racism...

articles.title: Yes, American Police Act Like Occupying Armies. They Literally Studied Their Tactics
articles.description: The founders of modern policing quelled foreign uprisings. 'Demilitarizing' police will be harder than taking away their tanks

articles.title: We Can No Longer Ignore the Potential of Psychedelic Drugs to Treat Depression
articles.description: At Imperial College we've been comparing psilocybin to conventional antidepressants – and the results are likely to be game-changing, says Robin Carhart-Harris

articles.title: A New CDC Survey Finds That Some Americans Are Misusing Disinfectants
articles.description: A new survey by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has found that some Americans are misusing cleaning and disinfectant products to prevent coronavirus. Some practices include misting their bodies with disinfectant and gargling bleach.

articles.title: It's Official: U.S. Economy Is in a Recession
articles.description: The committee tasked with marking U.S. business cycles says the economy peaked in February and has since been in a recession triggered by the pandemic. But it says the recession could be short-lived.

articles.title: Protests About Police Brutality Are Met With Wave of Police Brutality Across US
articles.description: Use of teargas, batons, pepper spray, fists, feet and vehicles against protesters sparks lawsuits and international condemnation

articles.title: Police Tactics Could Turn Protests Into Covid-19 Hot Spots
articles.description: Sure, large crowds already carry a risk of transmission. It's just worse when you teargas people, make them cough on each other, and bus them to jail.

articles.title: The Unluckiest Generation in U.S. History
articles.description: Millennials have faced the worst economic odds, and many will never recover.

articles.title: Police Misconduct Records Are Secret. Protests May Finally Change That.
articles.description: A decades-old New York State law that has kept police behavior from public scrutiny may finally be overturned.

articles.title: Trump Signs Order Removing Environmental Review of Major Projects
articles.description: President Trump signed an executive order Thursday evening that would waive requirements under a suite of environmental laws, a move the administration says will boost the economy amid the coronavirus pandemic.

articles.title: Amid Pandemic and Protests, Trump Fast-Tracks Dangerous Fossil Fuel Infrastructure
articles.description: Amid nationwide protests against racist police brutality and a pandemic that's disproportionately affecting Black people, on Thursday night, Trump signed an executive order directing federal agencies to fast track the construction of projects that will put communities of color at risk.

articles.title: Americans Are Drinking Bleach and Dunking Food in It to Prevent COVID-19
articles.description: Thirty-nine percent of surveyed people admitted to at least one risky practice.

articles.title: Pentagon War Game Includes Scenario for Military Response to Domestic Gen Z Rebellion
articles.description: The 2018 war game envisioned a 'Zbellion' by a tech-savvy generation that no longer believed in the American dream.

articles.title: Buffalo Police Said Protester With Head Wound 'Tripped and Fell.' Video Shows They Lied.
articles.description: Police officers in Buffalo, New York were caught on camera shoving a 75-year-old protester to the ground, injuring him at a protest against police brutality.

articles.title: COVID Vaccine Execs Hyped Vague Data to Cash in $90M in Stock, Watchdog Says
articles.description: Executives allegedly 'exploited widespread fears' of pandemic to make millions.
